Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Descriptive and Comparative Study of Akuntsu

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports the fieldwork and research for Carolina Aragon's doctoral dissertation to produce a comprehensive grammar of Akuntsú, a Tupían language spoken by monolinguals in Rondônia, Brazil. Until recently the Akuntsú people were an isolated indigenous group, but now, because of a genocidal massacre, there are only five remaining speakers. This has left Akuntsú a critically endangered language.

This project's main goal is to provide a comprehensive grammar of the language which will be informed by language typology and current linguistic theory. The grammatical description of Akuntsú will contribute to our understanding of the typological traits of the Tuparían subfamily and to linguistic typology in general. Ultimately it will also contribute to the reconstruction of Proto-Tuparían, with implications for Proto-Tupían.

Other documentary materials will also be produced; for example, important aspects of Akuntsú culture and history that have survived despite of the traumatic past will be recorded and archived. Documentation and production of linguistic, ethnographic, and lexicographic materials will be important not only to represent the structure of the language, but also to reveal the way that Akuntsú people see and understand their world. As part of a long-term goal, pedagogical materials will be created and the dictionary will be expanded ultimately to produce a talking dictionary.

By studying a group that still lives as its ancestors did, this project will provide contributions for scientific fields interested in the study of Amazonian native inhabitants and their cultural diversity. The general public will also benefit from having access to data and materials which will not only be relevant for linguistics, but also to scholars interested in learning more about Brazilian indigenous languages, society, and culture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a very successful project. Its major goal is also its major outcome: Carolina Coelho Aragon’s PhD dissertation, A grammar of Akuntsu, a Tupían language. The results also contribute to linguistic typology generally and to the field of language documentation, especially among monolinguals. It provide linguistic materials for several additional purposes, disseminated in the form of scientific articles and local publications, a dictionary, booklets for pedagogical purposes, and archived high-qualified materials for linguistic and ethnographic documentation.

Akuntsú is a member of the Tuparían subfamily of Tupían languages. The work is also a major contribution to Tupían linguistics, and in particular to Tuparían. The research has analyzed and explained major aspects of Akuntsu? grammar. The findings test several theoretical claims in the linguistic literature. For example, the analysis of personal pronouns and how they interact with verbs (verb alignment relations) shows that current theories are not fully adequate for describing these facts. The results also contribute to understanding the history of these languages and of the people who speak them, for example providing the evidence needed for determining the role of Tuparían in the classification of Tupían languages.

The project contributes beyond its immediate linguistic goals, with information valuable to understanding the language and culture of the Akuntsú, of whose tribe only six members survived a massacre in the late 1990’s – all monolingual speakers of their language. It contributes to methods for monolingual fieldwork. It provides valued information relevant to the indigenous peoples of Brazil in general, especially useful to the National Foundation of Indians in Brazil (FUNAI), the organization  responsible for the protection and promotion of Indigenous rights.
